p.text: [Div 2 insrt Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[10], effective 9 June 2006]
The provisions of this Division comprise uniform rules developed under the auspices of the Australian Council of Chief Justices.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.10] r 25.10 Interpretation (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Interpretation (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 1 )

p.text: In this Division:
has the meaning given by . rule 25.12 .
includes a court outside New South Wales, whether inside or outside Australia.
means a person who applies for a freezing order or an ancillary order.
has the meaning given by rule 25.11 .
means a person against whom a freezing order or an ancillary order is sought or made.
The definition of judgment in the Federal Court Rules is not included above. The word is defined in section 3 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 for the purposes of that Act and these rules.
In any notice of motion for a freezing order, a party should be referred to by the appropriate expression prescribed by rule 18.3.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.11] r 25.11 Freezing order (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Freezing order (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 2 )

p.text: The court may make an order (a freezing order), upon or without notice to a respondent, for the purpose of preventing the frustration or inhibition of the court’s process by seeking to meet a danger that a judgment or prospective judgment of the court will be wholly or partly unsatisfied.
A freezing order may be an order restraining a respondent from removing any assets located in or outside Australia or from disposing of, dealing with, or diminishing the value of, those assets.
Legislation cited in [25.11.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 18.1, r 25.14.

An application for a freezing order should comply with the substance of the requirements contained in Practice Note SC Gen 14. The application should be made by motion in the proceedings ( r 18.1 of the UCPR) and supported by affidavit evidence. The affidavits supporting the application should provide the following information:
details of the judgment or the unlitigated cause of action, on which the application is based;
the amount of the claim;
the nature and value of the respondent’s assets (so far as they are known);
the identity of any person, other than the respondent, who, the applicant believes, may be affected by the order and how that person may be affected by it; and
if the application is made without notice to the respondent, any possible defence that the respondent might have.

An applicant for an ex parte freezing order is under a duty to disclose all material facts to the court: see Practice Note SC Gen 14 at [19] and [25.11.25] . While the rules specifically contemplate that applications for freezing orders may be made ex parte, the exceptional nature of the order and its possible adverse consequences make it generally undesirable for an application to proceed ex parte unless there are substantial reasons for doing so: see Lunn v All Starr Video Ltd (1993) The Times, 25 March 1993 (ex parte application made during course of trial).
Legislation cited in [25.11.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 25.14, rr 25.14(6), 25.15.

The general power conferred by the present rule is complemented by the more specific provisions in r 25.14 of the UCPR, although those provisions do not limit the other powers a court has to make asset preservation orders: rr 25.14(6) and 25.15 of the UCPR. The basis of both the present rules, and the inherent or implied powers, is the necessity of ensuring the effective exercise of the court's jurisdiction, by authorising orders restraining an asset disposal that involves a real risk any judgment in the proceedings may not be satisfied: Mareva Compania Naviera SA v International Bulkcarriers SA [1980] 1 All ER 213; [1975] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 509 ; Patrick Stevedores Operations No 2 Pty Ltd v Maritime Union of Australia (No 3) (1998) 195 CLR 1; 153 ALR 643; [1998] HCA 30; BC9801511 ; Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 380; 162 ALR 294; [1999] HCA 18; BC9902073 at [42] ; Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435; 162 ALR 336; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 at [50]–[52] ; Jackson v Sterling Industries Ltd (1987) 162 CLR 612 at 623; 71 ALR 457; BC8701781 ; Tagget v Sexton (2009) 255 ALR 522; [2009] NSWCA 91; BC200903213 at [33]–[51], [62]–[66] (NSWDC has implied power to issue an asset preservation order against third parties); and see Walton v Gardiner (1993) 177 CLR 378; 112 ALR 289; BC9303612 ; Patterson v BTR Engineering (Aust) Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 319 ; Riley McKay Pty Ltd v McKay [1982] 1 NSWLR 264; (1982) 7 ACLR 116 . Although orders of this kind were commonly called “Mareva injunctions”, the “freezing order” terminology used in the present rules reflects the fact that the conceptual basis of the powers is distinct from that of the equitable injunction: Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd, above, at [26]–[27] , [42] and [79] (preference expressed for the use of the term “asset preservation” order) and is consistent with the usage in the English Civil Procedure Rules 1998.

level.toc-caption: [25.11.15] Circumstances in which freezing orders may be made

p.text: Legislation cited in [25.11.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 25.14.

heading.title: Circumstances in which freezing orders may be made

p.text: The powers conferred by the rules are substantially free of technical limitations relating to the nature or status of the applicant’s cause of action: see r 25.14 and contrast Siskina v Distos Compania Naviera SA (The Siskina) [1979] AC 210; [1977] 3 All ER 803 ). The Court may make a freezing order in a wide variety of circumstances. Orders may be made:
before a cause of action has accrued (a “prospective” cause of action): see 25.14;
against a person out of the jurisdiction, if the relevant assets are in Australia: see r 25.16 (“long arm” service);
to aid in the enforcement of a Mareva order made in a foreign court: Davis v Turning Properties Pty Ltd (2005) 222 ALR 676; [2005] NSWSC 742; BC200505413 ;
in aid of foreign proceedings where the respondent has assets within the jurisdiction: see r 25.14;

before or after judgment (eg, to aid the execution of a judgment): Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435; 162 ALR 336; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 ; Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 380; 162 ALR 294; [1999] HCA 18; BC9902073 at [43] ; Stewart Chartering Ltd v C & O Managements SA [1980] 1 All ER 718; [1980] 1 WLR 460 ; Orwell Steel (Erection & Fabrication) Ltd v Asphalt & Tarmac (UK) Ltd [1985] 3 All ER 747; [1984] 1 WLR 1097 ;

after judgment as an interlocutory measure in appeal proceedings: Tomasetti v Brailey [2012] NSWCA 6; BC201200858 at [13] (although, depending upon the reasons for the failure of the plaintiff’s claim at trial, the occasions for the exercise of the power are likely to be limited by the UCPR r 25.14(1)(b) requirement that an applicant have a “good arguable cause of action”.

level.toc-caption: [25.11.17] “disposing of, dealing with, or diminishing the value of … assets”

heading.title: “disposing of, dealing with, or diminishing the value of … assets”

p.text: See notes at [25.14.20] .

The jurisdiction to grant freezing orders is not intended to enable a plaintiff or judgment debtor to obtain security for its judgment in advance of execution. It is founded on the jurisdiction of the court to prevent abuses of its process by preventing a defendant or judgment debtor from embarking on a course of conduct which would have the effect of defeating the court’s jurisdiction. The fact that a judgment may not be satisfied for reasons of impecuniosity does not mean that there is an abuse of process: Finn v Carelli [2007] NSWSC 261; BC200701819 at [5] ; Perpetual Nominees Ltd v Taouk [2009] NSWSC 605; BC200905704 ; Lake v Crawford (No 2) [2010] NSWSC 419; BC201002844 (no dealing that had the characteristics of an attempt to avoid the reach of the proceedings such as the dissipation or disposal of assets or anything similar); In the matter of Re C & L Cameron Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 676; BC201204319 (obiter — no basis for freezing order — no evidence of a reasonable apprehension that any moneys released would be dissipated in a manner designed to frustrate the processes of the Court).

level.toc-caption: [25.11.20] Assets or respondents outside Australia — resident defendants

p.text: Legislation cited in [25.11.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 25.16.

heading.title: Assets or respondents outside Australia — resident defendants

p.text: The rules permit freezing orders to be made preventing asset transfers by resident defendants: Z Ltd v A-Z [1982] QB 558; [1982] 1 All ER 556 ; Iraqi Ministry of Defence v Arcepey Shipping Co SA [1981] QB 65; [1980] 1 All ER 480 ; Barclay-Johnson v Yuill [1980] 3 All ER 190; [1980] 1 WLR 1259 (threat of removal from the jurisdiction). That power extends to the transfer of assets that are outside the jurisdiction, and especially to the transfer of assets that have already been removed from the jurisdiction: Ballabil Holdings Pty Ltd v Hospital Products Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 155; 3 ACLC 220 . The power to make a freezing order also extends to prevent foreign residents removing assets from the jurisdiction (see r 25.16 of the UCPR) where the removal involves the danger of frustrating enforcement by the potential judgment creditor: Rasu Maritima SA v Perusahaan Pertambangan Minyak Dan Gas Bumi Negara (The Pertamina) [1978] QB 644; [1977] 3 All ER 324 ; Siskina v Distos Compania Naviera SA (The Siskina) [1979] AC 210; [1977] 3 All ER 803 ; Third Chandris Shipping Corporation v Unimarine SA [1979] QB 645; [1979] 2 All ER 972 ; Chartered Bank v Daklouche [1980] 1 All ER 205; [1980] 1 WLR 107 ; Rahman (Prince Abdul) bin Turki Al-Sudairy v Abu-Taha [1980] 3 All ER 409; [1980] 1 WLR 1268 ; Iraqi Ministry of Defence v Arcepey Shipping Co SA, above; Stewart Chartering Ltd v C & O Managements SA [1980] 1 All ER 718; [1980] 1 WLR 460 ; A v C [1981] QB 956; [1980] 2 All ER 347 . The power does not apply to assets that are wholly outside the court's jurisdiction: Ashtiani v Kashi [1987] QB 888; [1986] 2 All ER 970; [1986] 3 WLR 647 .

Where an application for a freezing order is made without notice to the affected party, the applicant has the same obligation that applies to any ex parte application and is required to disclose to the court all material facts: Thomas A Edison Ltd v Bullock (1912) 15 CLR 679 at 681–2; [1912] HCA 72 per Isaacs J; Town & Country Sport Resorts (Holdings) Pty Ltd v Partnership Pacific Ltd (1988) 20 FCR 540; 97 ALR 315 at 317 ; Print Management Australia Pty Ltd v Pasupati [2008] NSWSC 342; BC200802550 (applicant did not disclose to the court that it had lodged a caveat on the title to the property the subject of the order — freezing order dissolved) and see [25.1.30] . That obligation includes disclosure of possible defences to the claim and also disclosure of any matters that cast doubt on the substance of the applicant’s undertaking as to damages: Practice Note SC Gen 14 at [19].

If a freezing order is made without notice to the defendant or respondent, it should be expressed to operate only until the return date of the formal motion by which the substantive application is made. That return date should be a short period (1 to 2 days) after the interim order has been made: Practice Note SC Gen 14 at [9]. On the return day the applicant bears the onus of justifying continuation of the freezing order: see [25.1.40] .

Any freezing order should be supported by the applicant’s undertaking as to damages: Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 380; 162 ALR 294; [1999] HCA 18; BC9902073 at [42] ; Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435; 162 ALR 336; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 ; Frigo v Culhaci (NSWCA, Mason P, Sheller JA and Sheppard AJA, 17 July 1998, unreported, BC9803225) (legal practitioners should obtain appropriate instructions and offer, rather than wait for the court to exact, an undertaking as to damages). Security may be required to support the undertaking: see further [25.8.5] , [25.8.10] and Practice Note SC Gen 14 at [16] and [17].

The purpose of a freezing order is only to prevent the improper disposal of assets by a judgment debtor. The order only operates “in personam”. It does not confer any property interest on the judgment creditor and, in particular, does not confer any priority over any other creditors of the defendant: Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 380; 162 ALR 294; [1999] HCA 18; BC9902073 at [50] ; Iraqi Ministry of Defence v Arcepey Shipping Co SA [1981] QB 65; [1980] 1 All ER 480 ; Barclay-Johnson v Yuill [1980] 3 All ER 190; [1980] 1 WLR 1259 ; Riley McKay Pty Ltd v McKay [1982] 1 NSWLR 264; (1982) 7 ACLR 116 : see also Practice Note SC Gen 14 at [5].
Legislation cited in [25.11.45] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(CTH) Corporations Act 2001 s 1323.

The Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) provides the Australian Securities and Investments Commission with power to seek a form of statutory freezing order: see Corporations Act 2001 s 1323 ; ASIC v Carey (No 3) (2006) 232 ALR 577; 57 ACSR 307; [2006] FCA 433; BC200602423 ; ASIC v Krecichwost (2007) 213 FLR 314; 64 ACSR 411; [2007] NSWSC 948; BC200707363 ; ASIC v Banovec (No 2) (2007) 214 FLR 33; 25 ACLC 1205; [2007] NSWSC 961; BC200707402 ; ASIC v Burnard (2007) 64 ACSR 360; 25 ACLC 1505; [2007] NSWSC 1217; BC200709265 ; ASIC v PJCB International Ltd [2009] NSWSC 34; BC200900451 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.12] r 25.12 Ancillary order (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Ancillary order (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 3 )

p.text: The court may make an order (an ancillary order) ancillary to a freezing order or prospective freezing order as the court considers appropriate.
Without limiting the generality of subrule (1), an ancillary order may be made for either or both of the following purposes:
eliciting information relating to assets relevant to the freezing order or prospective freezing order,
determining whether the freezing order should be made.

The most common ancillary order is an order for disclosure of assets. It will often be appropriate to order discovery in aid of a freezing order, in order to inform, and potentially ensure, the effective exercise of the power: Ballabil Holdings Pty Ltd v Hospital Products Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 155; 3 ACLC 220 ; A v C [1981] QB 956; [1980] 2 All ER 347 cited in Bax Global (Australia) Pty Ltd v Evans (1999) 47 NSWLR 538; [1999] NSWSC 815; BC9904569 ; see also Jackson v Sterling Industries Ltd (1987) 162 CLR 612; 71 ALR 457; BC8701781 ; Bankers Trust Co v Shapira [1980] 3 All ER 353; [1980] 1 WLR 1274 ; A J Bekhor & Co Ltd v Bilton [1981] QB 923; [1981] 2 All ER 565 . An appropriate example form of order for discovery is included in Practice Note SC Gen 14 . Other examples of possible ancillary orders include:

an order for the cross-examination of a respondent about asset disclosure: see Den Norske Bank ASA v Antonatos [1999] QB 271; [1998] 3 All ER 74 ; Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd v Cochran (NSWSC, Brownie J, 4 April 1996, unreported, BC9601226) (order allowing cross-examination of the defendant and accountant);
an order that a respondent direct its bank to disclose information to the applicant: see Bank of Crete SA v Koskotas [1991] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 587;

an order requiring the delivery up of specified assets: see Jackson v Sterling Industries Ltd (1987) 162 CLR 612; 71 ALR 457; BC8701781 citing CBS United Kingdom Ltd v Lambert [1983] Ch 37; [1982] 3 All ER 237 ;

an order restraining the respondent from leaving the jurisdiction: see Al Nahkel for Contracting & Trading Ltd v Lowe [1986] QB 235; [1986] 1 All ER 729 ; Bayer AG v Winter [1986] 1 All ER 733; [1986] 1 WLR 497 ; Jackson v Sterling Industries Ltd, above; Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd v Cochran, above;
an order for the transfer of assets from one foreign jurisdiction to another: see Derby & Co Ltd v Weldon (No 6) [1990] NLJR 1001; [1990] 3 All ER 263 ;

an order appointing a receiver to the respondent’s assets: see Hart v Emelkirk [1983] 3 All ER 15; [1983] 1 WLR 1289 ; Ballabil Holdings Pty Ltd v Hospital Products Ltd (1985) 1 NSWLR 155; 3 ACLC 220 ; Beach Petroleum NL v Johnson (1992) 9 ACSR 404; 11 ACLC 75 ; Australian Securities and Investments Commission v Burke [2000] NSWSC 694; BC200004093 at [8] . See P Biscoe QC, Mareva and Anton Piller Orders: Freezing and Search Orders, LexisNexis Butterworths, Sydney, 2005, Ch 4 for descriptions and further examples of ancillary orders;

an order requiring an affidavit disclosing all matters relating to the use and application of funds paid out and distributed to trust beneficiaries: Robmatjus Pty Ltd v Violet Home Loans Australia Pty Ltd [2007] VSC 165 at [74]; BC200704112 .

level.toc-caption: [25.12.10] Privilege in relation to ancillary orders

heading.title: Privilege in relation to ancillary orders

p.text: In relation to any ancillary orders made under the present rule, the court must afford the person affected a proper opportunity to invoke a claim for privilege under Evidence Act 1995 s 128A: see SC Gen 14 at [14]. Apart from that statutory provision, the asset preservation power would not extend to authorise compulsory disclosure contrary to the ordinary privilege against self-incrimination: Ross v Internet Wines Pty Ltd (2004) 60 NSWLR 436; [2004] NSWCA 195; BC200403868 at [1], [94]–[104], [111] (disapproving Bax Global (Australia) Pty Ltd v Evans, above).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.13] r 25.13 Respondent need not be party to proceeding (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Respondent need not be party to proceeding (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 4 )

p.text: The court may make a freezing order or an ancillary order against a respondent even if the respondent is not a party to a proceeding in which substantive relief is sought against the respondent.

level.toc-caption: [25.13.5] Persons against whom orders may be made

heading.title: Persons against whom orders may be made

p.text: Although freezing orders will ordinarily be sought against an existing party to the proceedings, it is not necessary that the plaintiff has commenced, or intends to commence, judicial proceedings specifically against the person sought to be bound: Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 380; 162 ALR 294; [1999] HCA 18; BC9902073 at [54], [57] ; Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435; 162 ALR 336; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 ; The Rena K [1979] QB 377 at 407; [1979] 1 All ER 397 ; Construction Engineering (Aust) Pty Ltd v Tambel (A'asia) Pty Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 274 — arbitration proceedings. Freezing orders may be made against any person into whose hands the relevant assets can be traced: Earthline Constructions Pty Ltd v State Rail Authority of NSW (NSWCA, Full Court, Kirby P, Mahoney and Meagher JJA, CA40310/92, 26 October 1992, unreported, BC9201522) (successor corporations); or against any person who has effective control over the defendant and the ability to deal with its assets: Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd, above, at [46] . An order may also be made against any person whose assets the defendant could require to be applied in discharge of the plaintiff's claim: Winter v Marac (Aust) Ltd (1986) 6 NSWLR 11 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.14] r 25.14 Order against judgment debtor or prospective judgment debtor or third party (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Order against judgment debtor or prospective judgment debtor or third party (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 5 )

p.text: This rule applies if:
judgment has been given in favour of an applicant by:
the court, or
in the case of a judgment to which subrule (2) applies — another court, or
an applicant has a good arguable case on an accrued or prospective cause of action that is justiciable in:
the court, or
in the case of a cause of action to which subrule (3) applies — another court.
This subrule applies to a judgment if there is a sufficient prospect that the judgment will be registered in or enforced by the court.
This subrule applies to a cause of action if:
there is a sufficient prospect that the other court will give judgment in favour of the applicant, and
there is a sufficient prospect that the judgment will be registered in or enforced by the court.

The court may make a freezing order or an ancillary order or both against a judgment debtor or prospective judgment debtor if the court is satisfied, having regard to all the circumstances, that there is a danger that a judgment or prospective judgment will be wholly or partly unsatisfied because any of the following might occur:
the judgment debtor, prospective judgment debtor or another person absconds,
the assets of the judgment debtor, prospective judgment debtor or another person are:
removed from Australia or from a place inside or outside Australia, or
disposed of, dealt with or diminished in value.

The court may make a freezing order or an ancillary order or both against a person other than a judgment debtor or prospective judgment debtor (a third party) if the court is satisfied, having regard to all the circumstances, that:
there is a danger that a judgment or prospective judgment will be wholly or partly unsatisfied because:
the third party holds or is using, or has exercised or is exercising, a power of disposition over assets (including claims and expectancies) of the judgment debtor or prospective judgment debtor, or
the third party is in possession of, or in a position of control or influence concerning, assets (including claims and expectancies) of the judgment debtor or prospective judgment debtor, or

a process in the court is or may ultimately be available to the applicant as a result of a judgment or prospective judgment, under which process the third party may be obliged to disgorge assets or contribute toward satisfying the judgment or prospective judgment.
Nothing in this rule affects the power of the court to make a freezing order or ancillary order if the court considers it is in the interests of justice to do so.
Legislation cited in [25.14.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 11.4, r 13.1, r 25.14(3).

The rule requires a freezing order applicant to establish either that it is a judgment creditor or that it has a “good arguable case” on a justiciable cause of action. The “good arguable case” criterion is a lesser standard than the “prima facie cause of action” requirement favoured by the majority in Patterson v BTR Engineering (Aust) Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 319 . The “good arguable case” criterion has been regarded as capable of being satisfied without either involving or requiring any prediction about the likely ultimate success of the claim: Ninemia Maritime Corp v Trave GmbH & Co KG (The Niedersachsen) [1984] 1 All ER 398 at 404; [1983] 1 WLR 1412; [1983] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 600 at 605 per Mustill J (a good arguable case “is one which is more than barely capable of serious argument, and yet not necessarily one the judge considers would have better than a 50% chance of success”). The reference to “sufficient prospect” in r 25.14(3) suggests that the “good arguable case” expression has been used in that sense in the present rule. Such a standard is consistent with the approach taken in Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 380 at 408; 162 ALR 294; [1999] HCA 18; BC9902073 (“a reasonably arguable case on legal as well as factual matters”) and also the approach taken in the exercise of other analogous discretionary powers, such as leave to proceed under r 11.4 and summary judgment under r 13.1 of the UCPR: see Agar v Hyde (2000) 201 CLR 552; 173 ALR 665; [2000] HCA 41; BC200004311 and [13.1.5] – [13.1.10] . For a further example of the application of the test see Errigal Ltd v Equatorial Mining Ltd [2006] NSWSC 953; BC200607673 ; Pure Logistics v Scott [2007] NSWSC 595; BC200704439 at [12] ; Westpac Banking Corp v McArthur [2007] NSWSC 1347; BC200710208 (“good arguable” case against one respondent and not the other).

Depending on the particular circumstances, the failure of the claim at trial must detract from the ability of an unsuccessful plaintiff appellant to satisfy the requirement of demonstrating they have a “good arguable case”. Nevertheless, there is power to make a freezing order under the present rule, in favour of a plaintiff appellant: Tomasetti v Brailey [2012] NSWCA 6; BC201200858 at [13].

level.toc-caption: [25.14.10] Accrued or prospective cause of action

heading.title: Accrued or prospective cause of action

p.text: The alternative expression “accrued or prospective cause of action” means that an applicant for a freezing order does not have to demonstrate that it has an accrued cause of action against the person sought to be made the subject of the order: Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd, above, at [12]–[48] ; Bank of Queensland Ltd v Grant [1984] 1 NSWLR 409; (1984) 54 ALR 306 . In this respect the rule is consistent with a number of Australian cases dealing with the scope of the inherent or incidental powers: see Construction Engineering (Aust) Pty Ltd v Tambel (A'asia) Pty Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 274 ; Coxton Pty Ltd v Milne (NSWCA, 20 December 1985, Hope, Priestley and Glass JJA, unreported, BC8501037); Deputy Commissioner of Taxation (ACT) v Sharp (1988) 82 ACTR 1; (1988) 91 FLR 70 (Mareva order granted before tax assessment became payable); Patterson v BTR Engineering (Aust) Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 319 at 329 per Rogers AJA. The specific provisions of the rule obviate the need for any further consideration of whether the inherent or incidental power should properly be regarded as limited to instances where the applicant has an accrued cause of action: see Siskina v Distos Compania Naviera SA (The Siskina) [1979] AC 210; [1977] 3 All ER 803 ; Veracruz Transportation Inc v V C Shipping Co Inc [1992] 1 Lloyd’s Rep 353 (the court cannot make an order expressed to take effect as soon as the cause of action is complete).

level.toc-caption: [25.14.12] Cause of action justiciable in another court

p.text: Legislation cited in [25.14.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 25.14(3).

heading.title: Cause of action justiciable in another court

p.text: The powers conferred by the present rule only apply to a cause of action justiciable in another court, where that court’s judgment will be registered in or enforced by the court: UCPR r 25.14(3) ; Anderson v Williams [2010] NSWSC 1381; BC201009189 at [4], (no power to grant freezing order in aid of Family Court proceedings). However this limitation does not restrict the making of an order in the potential exercise of the court’s incidental power to ensure the effective exercise of its own jurisdiction: see Tagget v Sexton (2009) 255 ALR 522; [2009] NSWCA 91; BC200903213 at [63]–[66], [139], [141]–[151] .

level.toc-caption: [25.14.15] Cause of action — no order to aid recovery of penalties

p.text: Legislation cited in [25.14.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 25.14(6).

heading.title: Cause of action — no order to aid recovery of penalties

p.text: Despite the arguable width of the definition of “judgment” in s 3 of the CPA, and the preservation of the court’s inherent and incidental powers in r 25.14(6) of the UCPR , the rule only applies where a judgment has been given “in favour of” an applicant or where there is a “cause of action” against the defendant. It has been held that the power to make a freezing order does not apply in relation to proceedings to secure the payment of a civil penalty provided for under a statutory provision: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) v Chaste Corp (No 1) (2003) 127 FCR 418; 44 ACSR 668; [2003] FCA 180; BC200300849 .

level.toc-caption: [25.14.20] Danger that a judgment will be unsatisfied — danger of absconding or removal or loss of assets

p.text: Legislation cited in [25.14.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 25.14(4), (5).

heading.title: Danger that a judgment will be unsatisfied — danger of absconding or removal or loss of assets

p.text: The threshold criterion for the exercise of the power to grant a freezing order is the court’s satisfaction of a danger that a judgment will be wholly or partly unsatisfied as a result of either an irregular asset dealing or the judgment debtor absconding: see UCPR r 25.14(4) and (5) . Even though the requisite satisfaction must be derived after a consideration of “all the circumstances” the criterion is inherently impressionistic. In order to counsel against both the risk of unduly subjective apprehensions, and to avoid freezing orders being granted as a matter of course, the courts have frequently characterised such orders as being exceptional in nature and expressed the need for caution in the exercise of the power, particularly in relation to the width of the orders that may be made: Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 380; 162 ALR 294; [1999] HCA 18; BC9902073 at [51] , [53] : see also Practice Note SC Gen 14 at [6] (see [SC Gen 14] in vol 2). Consistent with that approach the courts have favoured the view that the “danger” to which the power is directed exists if there is a real risk a person will deal with assets to prevent the enforcement and satisfaction of any judgment in the proceedings: Patrick Stevedores Operations No 2 Pty Ltd v Maritime Union of Australia (No 3) (1998) 195 CLR 1; 153 ALR 643; [1998] HCA 30; BC9801511 ; Ninemia Maritime Corporation v Trave GmbH & Co KG (The Niedersachsen) [1984] 1 All ER 398; [1983] 1 WLR 1412; [1983] 2 Lloyd’s Rep 600 (order refused — no serious risk of frustration of the judgment — large corporation with its principal place of business in a country that provided for reciprocal enforcement of judgments); Patterson v BTR Engineering (Aust) Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 319 at 321, 326 ; Frigo v Culhaci [1998] NSWCA 88; BC9803225 (mere apprehension of insolvency — order refused); Finn v Carelli [2007] NSWSC 261; BC200701819 (factors relied upon otherwise explainable — not sufficiently serious risk of dissipation to warrant continuation of freezing order); Vaughan v Duncan [2007] NSWSC 811; BC200705773 (no continuation of order — no apprehension of dissipation); Perpetual Nominees Ltd v Taouk BC200905704 (freezing order refused — factors relied upon otherwise explained). Such a risk may exist as a result of a particular transaction even in the absence of any demonstrable positive intention to frustrate a judgment: Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 380; 162 ALR 294; [1999] HCA 18; BC9902073 at [26] .

It is sufficient if there is a danger that assets will be dealt with in a way which will in fact prevent the plaintiff from recovering on any judgment: Patterson v BTR Engineering Australia Ltd (1989) 18 NSWLR 319 at 321 ; Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd, above, at [26] ; Harrison Partners Construction Pty Ltd v Jevena Pty Ltd [2005] 225 ALR 369; BC200511119 at [42]–[43] (real risk that the defendant would deal with assets by investing in a proposed business albeit bona fide, that the business would fail, leaving insufficient funds to satisfy any judgment); Electric Mobility Company Pty Ltd v Whiz Enterprises Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 580; BC200604271 (applicant must establish danger by evidence, assertion is not sufficient); Errigal Ltd v Equatorial Mining Ltd [2006] NSWSC 953; BC200607673 at [54] and following (freezing order made — defendant did not conduct business activity in Australia, defendant taken over by another company with no business activity in Australia and defendant may be restructured, no evidence that the making of the order would cause hardship); Westpac Banking Corp v McArthur [2007] NSWSC 1347; BC200710208 (evidence of dishonest conduct and intention to move assets offshore).

level.toc-caption: [25.14.25] Form of the order — general considerations

heading.title: Form of the order — general considerations

p.text: The purpose of a freezing order is to prevent the improper dissipation of assets that would frustrate satisfaction of any judgment on the applicant’s claim. A necessary corollary of this purpose is that any freezing order should be confined to the amount of the claim — assuming it is presently able to be quantified (see Practice Note SC Gen 14 at [11] — and should not restrict the ability of the respondent to deal with their assets to the extent that their value exceeds the amount of their potential liability on the claim: Z Ltd v A-Z [1982] QB 558; [1982] 1 All ER 556 ; Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 380; 162 ALR 294; [1999] HCA 18; BC9902073 at [72] ; Clark Equipment Credit of Aust Ltd v Como Factors Pty Ltd (1988) 14 NSWLR 552 . Similarly the order ought to generally permit the respondent to resort to their assets for the purpose of meeting ordinary living expenses and properly incurred liabilities, including the costs of relevant legal proceedings: see Practice Note SC Gen 14 at [12]; PCW (Underwriting Agencies) Ltd v Dixon [1983] 2 All ER 158; [1983] BCLC 105 ; CBS United Kingdom Ltd v Lambert [1983] Ch 37; [1982] 3 All ER 237 ; Iraqi Ministry of Defence v Arcepey Shipping Co SA [1981] QB 65; [1980] 1 All ER 480 ; Frigo v Culhaci (NSWCA, Mason P, Sheller JA and Sheppard AJA, 17 July 1998, unreported, BC9803225); Glenwood Management Group Pty Ltd v Mayo [1991] 2 VR 49; BC9000732 ; Polly Peck International Plc v Nadir (No 2) [1992] 4 All ER 769; [1993] BCLC 187 . However, a permissive qualification of this latter kind on the scope of a freezing order will not be appropriate if the respondent has other assets to which they could resort for the purpose of meeting their relevant expenses: Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd v Buck [1982] 2 NSWLR 889 .

level.toc-caption: [25.14.30] Form of the order — Practice Notes

heading.title: Form of the order — Practice Notes

p.text: A generally appropriate form of freezing order, which may be subject to modification appropriate for particular circumstances, is set out in the Supreme Court Practice Note SC Gen 14 . A simplified form of inter partes Mareva (freezing) order approved by the High Court in Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 380; 162 ALR 294; [1999] HCA 18; BC9902073 is set out in Appendix E, P Biscoe QC, Mareva and Anton Piller Orders: Freezing and Search Orders, LexisNexis Butterworths, Sydney, 2005. Pages 183–96 of that work contain a useful further explanatory discussion about the desirable contents of a freezing order.

The uniform rules adopt the principles in Cardile v LED Builders Pty Ltd (1999) 198 CLR 380; 162 ALR 294; [1999] HCA 18; BC9902073 at [57] in relation to third parties. Third parties, such as banks, who are in possession of assets subject to a freezing order are bound by its terms as soon as they are notified of them. They are required to do all that they reasonably can to preserve the assets. The court may enforce its order against a third party through its contempt powers where a deliberate breach of the order can be shown: Z Ltd v A-Z [1982] QB 558; [1982] 1 All ER 556 ; Customs and Excise Commissioners v Barclays Bank plc [2007] 1 AC 181; [2006] 4 All ER 256; [2006] UKHL 28 ; P Biscoe QC, Mareva and Anton Piller Orders: Freezing and Search Orders, LexisNexis Butterworths, Sydney, 2005, Ch 4.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.15] r 25.15 Jurisdiction (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Jurisdiction (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 6 )

p.text: Nothing in this Division diminishes the inherent, implied or statutory jurisdiction of the court to make a freezing order or ancillary order.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.16] r 25.16 Service outside Australia of application for freezing order or ancillary order (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Service outside Australia of application for freezing order or ancillary order (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 7 )

p.text: An application for a freezing order or an ancillary order may be served on a person who is outside Australia (whether or not the person is domiciled or resident in Australia) if any of the assets to which the order relates are within the jurisdiction of the court.
Legislation cited in [25.16.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 11.1–11.12, r 25.14(3).

If the defendant is outside the jurisdiction, the power to grant a freezing order does not depend on the existence of a substantive cause of action in respect of which foreign service could be authorised under UCPR rr 11.1–11.12 : contrast Mercedes Benz AG v Leiduck [1996] AC 284; [1995] 3 All ER 929 (inherent or incidental power). Under the present rules a freezing order may be made in relation to causes of action justiciable in foreign courts, if the court is satisfied there is “sufficient prospect” of a judgment being obtained that would be enforceable by the court in which the freezing order application is made: see UCPR r 25.14(3) .

Guidelines for the exercise of discretion to grant leave to enforce a worldwide freezing order (ie, a freezing order in respect of foreign assets) are discussed in Dadourian Group International Inc v Simms [2006] 3 All ER 48; [2006] 1 WLR 2499; [2006] EWCA Civ 399 at [25] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 25.17] r 25.17 Costs (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 8)

leg:heading.title: Costs (cf Federal Court Rules Order 25A, rule 8 )

p.text: The court may make any order as to costs as it considers appropriate in relation to an order made under this Division.
Without limiting the generality of subrule (1), an order as to costs includes an order as to the costs of any person affected by a freezing order or ancillary order.

An applicant for a freezing order must expect to pay all reasonable costs and expenses a third party (such as a bank) might incur in observing the terms of the order: see Project Development Co Ltd SA v K M K Securities Ltd [1983] 1 All ER 465; [1982] 1 WLR 1470 (third party bank awarded its costs incurred on a solicitor and own client basis); Norilya Minerals Pty Ltd v Ireland (1994) 12 WAR 485 (bank awarded indemnity costs against plaintiff).
